response:
<<<api>>>: Java's built-in Set interface
<<<code>>>:
```java
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Iterator;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Set;

public class Intersection {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List<Integer> list1 = new ArrayList<>();
        list1.add(1);
        list1.add(2);
        list1.add(3);

        List<Integer> list2 = new ArrayList<>();
        list2.add(2);
        list2.add(3);
        list2.add(4);

        List<Integer> list3 = new ArrayList<>();
        list3.add(1);
        list3.add(4);
        list3.add(5);

        Set<Integer> intersection = new HashSet<>();

        for (List<Integer> list : new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(list1, list2, list3))) {
            intersection.addAll(list);
        }

        System.out.println(intersection);
    }
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: You can use a HashSet to store the common elements between the lists. Iterate through each list and add all the elements to the HashSet. The resulting HashSet will contain the common elements between all the lists.
